content: A researcher discovered, that WhatsApp (or Facebook) could force the WhatsApp mobile client to generate new encryption keys. Due to this, WhatsApp would be able to intercept the key exchange and - of course - would be able to intercept the messages. This is how a man-in-the-middle attack works and it only works when both parties - which are communicating with each other - do not verify the fingerprints of the exchanged keys. Signal and WhatsApp are using a concept called “TOFU” or “Trust on first use”. This means, that when a key is exchanged, this key is trusted as long as the key does not change. Signal and WhatsApp have different default settings what happens, when the key-material of a contact changes: WhatsApp just notifies the user when key material changes. Signal blocks outgoing messages and does not send new messages to a user where the key material has changed. A Signal user has to manually verify the new key by default (in this case, a user should verify the key material in person by scanning the QR code of the fingerprint).

info.title: Why the "WhatsApp-backdoor" is not a WhatsApp-backdoor - slashcrypto's page
